answer_html: \(\displaystyle AA^* = U \Sigma ^2 U^T\)From this equation, we can see that our eigenvalues are the same as the last.However, the corresponding eigenvectors are now the columns of U.
answer_latex:
$\displaystyle AA^* = U \Sigma ^2 U^T$From this equation, we can see that our eigenvalues are the same as the
last.However, the corresponding eigenvectors are now the columns of U.
question: Section 201 07 (c)
sols_html:
The eigenvalues and eigenvectors for \(\displaystyle A^* A\):

\(\displaystyle A^* A = V \Sigma ^T \Sigma V^T\)

Since \(\displaystyle \Sigma ^T = \Sigma\),

\(\displaystyle \Sigma ^T \Sigma = \Sigma ^2\)

Which means that our eigenvalues are \(\displaystyle \sigma _1 ^2 , \ \sigma _2 ^2\), and \(0\)

and the eigenvectors are the columns of V.

The eigenvalues and eigenvectors for \(\displaystyle AA^*\):

\(\displaystyle AA^* = U \Sigma ^2 U^T\)

From this equation, we can see that our eigenvalues are the same as the last. However, the corresponding eigenvectors are now the columns of U.

$\displaystyle A^* A = V \Sigma ^T \Sigma V^T$

Since $\displaystyle \Sigma ^T = \Sigma$,

$\displaystyle \Sigma ^T \Sigma = \Sigma ^2$

Which means that our eigenvalues are
$\displaystyle \sigma _1 ^2 , \ \sigma _2 ^2$, and $0$

and the eigenvectors are the columns of V.

The eigenvalues and eigenvectors for $\displaystyle AA^*$:

$\displaystyle AA^* = U \Sigma ^2 U^T$

From this equation, we can see that our eigenvalues are the same as the
last. However, the corresponding eigenvectors are now the columns of U.
sols_raw:
The eigenvalues and eigenvectors for <math>\displaystyle A^* A</math>:

<math> \displaystyle A^* A = V \Sigma ^T \Sigma V^T</math>

Since <math> \displaystyle \Sigma ^T = \Sigma</math>,

<math> \displaystyle \Sigma ^T \Sigma = \Sigma ^2</math>

Which means that our eigenvalues are <math> \displaystyle \sigma _1 ^2 , \ \sigma _2 ^2</math>, and <math>0</math>

and the eigenvectors are the columns of V.

The eigenvalues and eigenvectors for <math> \displaystyle AA^*</math>:

<math> \displaystyle AA^* = U \Sigma ^2 U^T</math>

From this equation, we can see that our eigenvalues are the same as the last. However, the corresponding eigenvectors are now the columns of U.
statement_html:
Suppose that the matrix A has the following singular value decomposition:

\[\begin{aligned} A = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \sigma_2 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ -1\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

where \(\sigma_1 \geq \sigma_2 \geq 0\).

(c) What are the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A*A and AA*?
